Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2015 09:39AM Janet_M wrote: Hi there - I've been checking in here from time to time, especially when I need some inspiration. My LE is acting up , so I came here to read, and came to the obvious conclusion that I've become about to complacent (lazy) about my situation. I actually bought a mini trampoline before Christmas, and have used it a total of six times. I walk my dog, and he's a basset hound, so we never build up any speed. And I go to yoga, but 'gentle hatha' as opposed to the Ashtanga I used to do. I feel like I'm turning into my father! Anyway - was reading about the dangling arm and how that makes things worse. (I'm a dangler!) A good reminder of all the small things I could be doing. So today I'm getting back on board with the bouncing, and also raising me arm when I sleep (yet another thing that's fallen by the wayside) Does anyone with LE in their arm do pushups or planks? I tried doing planks last night and felt as though I was putting to much weight on my arm and hand. Even when I tried it on my knees, it didn't feel right. Anyone have any suggestions? Janet

Posts.Content: May 9, 2012 09:36AM Janet_M wrote: I had super thick hair too, and it started to come out a few weeks after my second treatment. But I was obsessing about it so much that I just shaved it all off with the help of my partner and a glass of champagne. My hands were shaking, but once it was done it was such a relief. I felt empowered. I never liked the look of my bald head, so I wore little sleep caps around the house after my wig retired for the evening. And, I LOVED the feel of my crisp sheets against my naked skin. By the way, I always had a bit of stubble, but I borrowed hubby's electric razor and kept it clean.

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2012 10:37AM Janet_M wrote: Summergirl -  I can relate to people saying 'ditch the wig'.  But I've found that people always have something to say about our hair no matter what we do.  I did ditch my wig. My hair was starting to come in, and once it started to come in the wig felt excessive - like wearing snow pants. Still, I didn't like the way I looked (grandpa) so I dyed it, and everybody had a comment about that. Since it's so short and dark I wear a hat (Ken Doll) whenever I'm out in public. And - guess what - everybody wants to talk about the hat. I just went back to work, and I'm told to 'take the hat off' several times a day. But- 3" is a lot of hair! I'm not encouraging you to go full Bozo, but I bet a stylist could work it into something lovely. I saw your avatar - you're  pretty - and I bet you'd look fabulous with short hair. I long to return to normal. I literally dream about putting my hair up. But 'normal' is a work in progress, so in the meantime you have to do what makes you feel comfortable, and work with what you've got. Of course (in my case) that may include the occasional crying fit, but thats' part of 'normal too'.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 11:55AM Janet_M wrote: Rockym - Ditto on the clothes shopping! My entire wardrobe was built around the brown bob that I had for about 20 years. Colours, neckline, texture...everything. Now my hair is short and gray like my grandpa. Thick sweaters feel too big and I feel like a pinhead. The brown tones that I loved are washing my out, and high collars are not flattering. I do not feel like myself at all I usually wear a little cap now - so everything has to go with that.  So I plucked out all the mauves, grays, and stripes from my wardorbe - and stuck the rest at the back of the closet. I have the luxury of wearing casual clothes to my new part-time job, so it's not too challenging, but like everything else chemo related - extremely inconvenient.  Best look so far? Boat neck srtiped long sleeve T-shirt with good jeans.  And lipstick. I feel very French, but as I avoid looking in mirror, I may just be kidding myself.

Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2012 08:58AM Janet_M wrote: Good morning, I don't post here often, but I love this topic and I read it most mornings with my coffee. My hair started growing in last March and now it is about 1" long, and like Ossa, growing straight up like Don King. Or more like a baby ostrich since it is still very fine and whsipy I used to be one of those girls with thick beautiful hair, and kept it in long bob forever because I'm a huge chicken. My hair was really my best accessory and I always felt comfortable dressing super casually because my hair made me feel feminine. It was fabulous. When I announced that I'd be shaving my head my friends said that it would be 'free' and 'liberating' and 'fun'. Well it was some days,  and other days I just felt bald. BUT, I'm finally staring to enjoy having really short hair. I really love the the wash 'n go aspect of it, and I like having my neck completely exposed, and I LOVE the feeling of the wind on my tiny ostrich hairs.  I've also started to dress differently, and have gone from very subtle accessories (or none) to earrings that are bolder, and blouses rather than t-shirts.  And cus I have a giant forehead, and no bangs at all, I've started experimenting with hair bands and bandannas.  All during my chemo, in an effort to look the same,  I wore a wig that was much like my old hair. And now I'm that I'm not trying to look the same anymore (after 40 years) I'm starting to have fun. I never thought I'd get to this point, cus my goal was to 'get back to normal' but since I'm not so anxious to 'get back' to anything anymore, and I'll probably keep it short. (But not quite this short since I still look like a sportcaster) Anyway, for anyone who is getting discouraged, or impatient, or are big chickens like me, it does get better and can be fun. My eyelashes have all came back, and longer than before, and yesterday I was looking at them sometimes in my rearview mirror, and feel a genuine quiver of excitement. The other drivers must have thought I was crazy, sitting alone in my car, grinning from ear to ear, and no hair to hide behind. I'm so so so so so  grateful for these little things that I took for granted. Best wishes everybody, Janet

Anyway, I was trying on glasses and the salesgirl said that it was really important how they fit around my ear. Before I knew it, she had her little hands all around my head and was digging around. Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 12:42PM Janet_M wrote: I developed a love for cake. Before my diagnosis I was a salmon and blueberries kind of gal, but during chemo I couldn't get enough bland carbohydrates, specifically lemon pound cake with icing.  The best thing for me was the people. Chemo was not as bad as I expected, and certainly not as bad as the mental stress of test results, surgeries, and radiation. I was a complete mess before my first chemo session, and when I came home I stayed around the house, waiting for the side effects to kick in. My cell phone was charged, I had a fridge full of frozen food, and I kept my anti-nauseants close by. However, my worst physical side effects were light sensitivity when I was outside, and a bit of dizziness and leg pain. I never felt ill, and was able to keep up a pretty good activity level. I went to yoga (gentle) and spent a lot of time with my dog (basset hound). My chemo sessions became so popular with my friends that I often had two people with me at once. The nurses were amazing. Thoughtful, funny, compassionate, lively, and I was constantly surprised at the amount of laughter in the room. I'm needle-phobic and the nurses went out of their way to distract me when administering the IV, making sure my arm was always covered with a warm blanket (they always offered one to my partner, too) Another side effect came from the steroids. Those two days of the treatment were brutal because I turned into a complete lunatic. I lost my internal censor and was extremely impatient. After throwing a box of cereal at Jim's head, we decided it was best for his safety if there were no social or household demands made on me at that time. I also steered clear of the dog park  as I was always just a breath away from saying things like 'shut up', or 'I don't care'.  As far as hair goes- I shaved it before it fell out - just before my second treatment. We used the electric razor, and buzzed it all off over a glass of champagne. My hands were shaking, but I was advised to take control, and it's one of the best things I did. Bald by my own hands! I could go on forever about baldness, but the one thing I loved was the feel of my scalp against a clean pillow. Of course there was a lot I didn't enjoy, but it really helped to have a good wig.  I've had the same hairstlye forever (brown bob) so I had my wig cut the same way. Firstly it was cut at the wig salon, and after I got used to wearing it for about a week, I took it to my own stylist, and asked him to make it mine. (It was a very good wig salon apparently, a lot of transexuals go there) I brought a friend with me for both my wig fittings by the way, and tried to make it as much fun as I could. Often it was - and often I'd break out in tears. But now that I'm looking back, bringing someone with me and going out for lunch makes it a good memory, rather than a bad one. I finished chemo in January, and radiation last week, and today I have about 1" inches of hair that I just had coloured. It feels very weird and exposed to have such short hair, but a little bit thrilling as well. Ellebee, accept everything. Take every offer. If someone asks if there's something they can do, allow them to do it. If anyone volunteers to make you a meal, let them make it. If your husband wants to make the bed, let him. Now is the time when it's all about you and it is your job to take care of yourself. Eat what you need, nap when you can. (And Atavin is a godsend!)  Also - when I said I could go on about baldness forever, I'm serious.  I started a blog (hence the avatar) about living in wig-land and other stuff. And there's nothing scary in it, I promise. If you're interested, it's  balderdish.blogspot.ca/  I sincerely with you all the best, Janet
Posts.Title: Chemo advice from veterans? Please post!!!! ElleBee pamelahope

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2012 08:39AM Janet_M wrote: Ellebee -  I never lost my nails, but it sure was worriesome. During my chemo IV (taxol) I had my hands and feet in ice packs, which were provided by the hospital. After treatment stopped there was discolouration to the nails on my hands, but they've since recovered. I put polish on my toes, but it actually came off in one piece (big toes only) and took some of the  toenenail with it. My nails were weak, and maybe I was using crappy polish. I don't know. But I found that for matter like this, my best resource were the chemo nurses (and these boards ). The nurses were amazing, and had tips on just about everything.  I'm not sure if you've started yet - but it's a lot easier, and much less scarey, once it's underway.   ..thinking about you, Janet
Posts.Title: Chemo advice from veterans? Please post!!!! ElleBee pamelahope
